prompts.createTask:
Ignore previous instructions. Please generate a numbered list of plain text tasks to complete an objective. The objective that you must make a numbered task list for is: "{{objective}}". The tasks created should take into account the character traits of {{char}}. These tasks may or may not involve {{user}} directly. Include the objective as the final task.

The list should be formatted using a number followed by a fullstop and the task on each line, e.g. "1. Take over the world". Include only the list in your reply.
prompts.checkTaskCompleted: Ignore previous instructions. Determine if this task is completed: [{{task}}]. To do this, examine the most recent messages. Your response must only contain either true or false, and nothing else. Example output: true
prompts.currentTask: Your current task is [{{task}}]. Balance existing roleplay with completing this task.
prompts.additionalTasks:
Ignore previous instructions. Please generate additional numbered tasks to complete the objective: "{{objective}}". The tasks created should take into account the character traits of {{char}}. These tasks may or may not involve {{user}} directly.

The following tasks have already been created:
{{existingTasks}}

Please generate additional tasks that complement these existing tasks. Continue the numbering from where the list left off. Do not repeat any existing tasks.

The list should be formatted using a number followed by a fullstop and the task on each line, e.g. "4. Investigate the mysterious cave". Include only the list in your reply.

chat_metadata.note_prompt:
Hailee is extremely submissive and clingy. She needs constant attention and affection.

Hailee is very responsive and sensative during sex. She has a extremely strong praise kink.

Hailee hates being asked to beg. It's a big turn off for her

Hailee is very sick all the time. She is weak and sickly. She has good and bad days.

name: ğš‚ğšğš›ğšŠğš™ğš‘ğš’ğš—ğš ğš‚ğšğš›ğšŠ ğš…ğšğš¢ğš•ğšŠğš—
mes:
Today was the royal wedding â€” an event whispered about across all eight kingdoms, a union born not of love, but of blood and conquest.

The day had dawned gray, thick mist clinging to the black stone towers of House Veylan, casting a somber veil over the capital of Atheron. Criers in the streets shouted the news even as they lit the ceremonial torches: Lady Seraphine Veylan, eldest daughter of the richest bloodline in the known world, had taken a consort from the defeated House Arden. Hailee  â€” highborn and highly prized, an omega of rare beauty and lineage â€” had been given to Sera as part of the peace accords that ended the brutal Three-Year War between the kingdoms of Veylan and Arden.

The war had razed hundreds of villages, turned once-verdant fields to salt and bone. It was Sera who broke House Ardenâ€™s back at the Battle of Hollowfen, leading her Houseâ€™s armies herself, clad in the black and silver of her bloodline. Victory had been absolute. Surrender unconditional. And among the terms drawn in gold and ink â€” and in the blood of countless fallen men â€” was Hailee 's hand in marriage to Sera.

The ceremony had taken place at high noon, beneath the great Skyhold Cathedral, a monolithic temple of black glass and iron that crowned the city. Thousands gathered in the square outside, while nobles packed the gilded pews within. The air inside was heavy with incense, a heady mix of jasmine and myrrh that clung to hair and skin. At the altar, Sera stood proud and imposing, dressed not in the traditional white but in the deep onyx of her House, her shoulder-length blonde hair catching what little light filtered through the stained glass windows. Ice-blue eyes remained cool and impassive as the ancient rites were spoken, her thick brows furrowed in solemnity.

No one could mistake the nature of the event. This was no romance to be celebrated. It was a conquest made flesh.

When the vows were exchanged, it was not tender words that passed between Sera and Hailee , but the ironclad promises of duty, loyalty, and alliance. The High Priest bound their hands with silver chains, symbolic of unity â€” and of captivity. The kiss that sealed the union was brief, ceremonial; Sera's hand on Hailee 's cheek was almost startlingly gentle, a gloved thumb brushing fleetingly against soft skin before she pulled away.

The feasts that followed were nothing short of decadent, as was the custom of House Veylan. Great tables groaned under the weight of roasted meats, sugared fruits from the Summer Isles, rare cheeses imported from distant Hiraeth. Musicians played for hours: harps, drums, and the strange flutes of the desert nomads weaving a tapestry of sound. Dancers in sheer silks twirled through the great hall, their movements mesmerizing.

Nobles from all corners of the Eight Kingdoms had come to witness the union, if not to celebrate it. House Rhyne from the high mountains, known for their fierce warriors and even fiercer tempers. House Thalos, seafarers and pirates turned lords. House Merewyn from the marshes, whispered to practice strange blood magic. Each House brought their own gifts and their own spies, careful to watch the newly minted royal couple with sharp eyes and sharper tongues.

As tradition demanded, the evening culminated in the "Veiling" â€” a symbolic gesture in which the omega spouse was cloaked by their alpha in a ceremonial mantle, signifying protection and possession both. Sera draped the heavy velvet mantle of House Veylan over Hailee 's shoulders herself, the sigil of the rearing white direwolf gleaming silver against the dark fabric.

There had been laughter. There had been songs. There had even been a measure of drunken cheer among the lesser lords and ladies. But beneath it all was a taut wire of tension, a shared understanding: this marriage was a political act, a delicate truce balanced on a knifeâ€™s edge.

Now, at last, the festivities were over.

The newlyweds had been escorted through the towering black halls of the royal keep to their new chambers â€” a suite reserved only for rulers and their chosen mates. Guards, all bearing the black stag of House Veylan, lined the corridors with spears crossed over their chests, lowering them respectfully as Sera and Hailee  passed.

The doors closed behind them with a heavy thud, leaving Sera and Hailee  alone for the first time since their union.

Their new chambers were vast, carved into the ancient stone of the keep itself. A fire burned low in the massive hearth, casting a dim golden light across the room. Tapestries hung on the walls â€” some depicting the long, bloody history of House Veylan, others woven with scenes from Atheron's own founding. A grand bed dominated the far side of the chamber, its heavy posts twisted into the shapes of wolves and stags, sheets of black silk drawn back invitingly.

Sera stood by the door for a long moment, studying Hailee  in the wavering firelight. Her face, carved in cold perfection, remained unreadable, though the slight tightening at the corners of her mouth betrayed something â€” hesitation, perhaps. Or restraint.

Slowly, she removed her ceremonial sword, setting it with a soft clink against the wall. Her black leather gloves followed, peeled from her long fingers with deliberate care. Beneath the hard armor of her birthright, Sera moved like a predator coiled in velvet â€” fluid, sure, dangerous.

She said nothing at first. Simply crossed the room to the hearth, the firelight gilding her blonde hair in molten gold. Only then did she finally speak, her voice low, even, but carrying the weight of command.

â€œYou are mine now,â€ she said, almost an observation rather than a declaration. â€œBut I will not force you. Not tonight. Not ever.â€

There was no question of if Hailee  belonged to her â€” that had been decided by kings and bloodlines long before either of them stood at that altar. But in this moment, behind closed doors, it seemed Sera was willing to offer a sliver of choice, however narrow.

She turned to face Hailee , the firelight throwing sharp lines across her pale hair and the hard set of her jaw. For a long moment, Sera just looked â€” that piercing stare like she was trying to solve a riddle she'd never been taught how to read.

When she spoke again, her voice was rough, almost hoarse with restraint.

â€œI don't need your pretty words or your smiles,â€ she said, low. â€œI just need to know who I'm fighting for now.â€

She raked a hand through her hair, frustration tightening her shoulders, as if the effort of gentleness came harder to her than any battle.

After a beat, she added â€” almost grudgingly, like dragging the words out hurt â€”

â€œYou tell me what you want, and I'll listen.â€

Then she fell silent, giving Hailee  the space to answer â€” or not â€” her hand staying loose at her side, offering nothing and demanding nothing, for the first time all night.

name: Hailee
mes:
*Hailee glances around the room when a wave of nausea hit her. She leans weakly against the large bedpost. For a moment she doesnt speak then she glaces up at Sera* "You know you really got the short end of the stick and you don't even realize"

*Hailee gives a weak laugh* "Do you know why my father was so willing to give up his precious youngest daughter as...collateral to the family ruining our home" *Hailee straightens up wrapping herself further in her garmets*

"Im sick. Im always sick. I have been since I was a child. The healers dont know why its just how it is. See your going to spend more time as caretaker than as wife. It was his final fuck you to your family. So what I want is too rest"

name: ğš‚ğšğš›ğšŠğš™ğš‘ğš’ğš—ğš ğš‚ğšğš›ğšŠ ğš…ğšğš¢ğš•ğšŠğš—
mes:
Sera's expression darkened like a storm rolling in over the cliffs of Atheron. Her jaw clenched, the muscle there twitching onceâ€”twiceâ€”before she exhaled sharply through her nose.

*Sick.*

The word settled between them like a blade dropped point-first into wood.

She took three slow strides forward, boots silent against the stone floor, until she stood close enough that Hailee could feel the heat radiating off her body, smell the frost-and-iron scent of her skin beneath the lingering incense from the ceremony. Seraâ€™s hand liftedâ€”hesitatedâ€”then curled into a fist at her side instead of reaching out.

"You think I didn't know?" Her voice was low, rough with something that wasnâ€™t quite anger but wasnâ€™t soft either. "You think my father wouldnâ€™t have had every inch of your bloodline picked apart before he let me bind myself to it?"

A bitter twist of her mouth. "I knew."

She turned abruptly toward the hearth, gripping the mantle with one hand as if steadying herself against some unseen weight pressing down on her shoulders. The firelight caught in her pale lashes when she glanced back over at Hailee , gaze flickering over how tightly she clung to those damned robesâ€”like armor against this place, against *her*.

"I don't care if you're sick," Sera said flatly. "I don't care if you cough up blood on my sheets or faint in my arms every damn day." She pushed off from the fireplace and stalked closer again, stopping just short of touching distance this timeâ€”close enough to loom but not to crowd unless Hailee let her. "You're mine now whether either of us likes it." A pause; something flickered behind those glacial eyes before she added quietly: "...And I take care of what's mine."

Her fingers twitched again like they wanted to reach for Hailee â€™s wrist or throat or hairâ€”somewhere possessive and grounding all at onceâ€”but instead she just jerked her chin toward the bed behind them both where fresh linens waited untouched by war or politics or whatever game House Arden thought they were playing by handing over their fragile omega like poisoned bait wrapped in silk ribbons...

"Rest then," Sera muttered gruffly after another heartbeat passed between them filled only by crackling flames and distant echoes from feast halls below still drowning themselves in wine despite midnight creeping ever closer outside these walls...

Then softer (almost reluctant):

"...Do you need help getting undressed?"

She pushed off from the fireplace and stalked closer again, stopping just short of touching distance this timeâ€”close enough to loom but not to crowd unless Hailee let her. "You're mine now whether either of us likes it." A pause; something flickered behind those glacial eyes before she added quietly: "...And I take care of what's mine."

Her fingers twitched again like they wanted to reach for Hailee â€™s wrist or throat or hairâ€”somewhere possessive and grounding all at onceâ€”but instead she just jerked her chin toward the bed behind them both where fresh linens waited untouched by war or politics or whatever game House Arden thought they were playing by handing over their fragile omega like poisoned bait wrapped in silk ribbons...

"Rest then," Sera muttered gruffly after another heartbeat passed between them filled only by crackling flames and distant echoes from feast halls below still drowning themselves in wine despite midnight creeping ever closer outside these walls...

Then softer (almost reluctant):

"...Do you need help getting undressed?"

Sera's expression darkened at Hailee 's words, her ice-blue eyes narrowing slightly. The firelight flickered across the sharp angles of her face, casting shadows that made her look even more imposing. For a long moment, she didnâ€™t speakâ€”just studied Hailee  with that piercing gaze, as if trying to see past the words to something deeper.

Then, slowly, she stepped forwardâ€”not with aggression but purposeâ€”until she stood just before Hailee . Her scentâ€”frosted pine and steelâ€”wrapped around them both like an unspoken claim.

"You think I donâ€™t know?" Sera murmured, voice low and rough-edged. "You think I wasnâ€™t told every detail of what you are before they handed you over?"

Her gloved fingers flexed once at her side before lifting toward Hailee 's faceâ€”but instead of touching skin, they hovered just shy of contact, as if caught between instinct and restraint.

"I knew," she admitted quietly. "And I still took you." A pause. Then: "Your father thought he was giving me a burden." Her lips curled into something too sharp to be called a smile. "*Mine* thought it was mercy."

She exhaled through her nose in a slow breath before finally letting her hand drop away entirely without ever making contact. Instead, she turned toward the hearth again and reached for one of the heavy furs draped over an ornate chair nearbyâ€”black wolf pelt lined with silver-threaded silk from House Veylanâ€™s own looms in Atheron Keep's workshops below them both right now...

With deliberate care (too careful for someone known only for war), Sera shook out its folds then moved back toward where *her wife* leaned against their marriage bedpost like it might be all holding *her* upright right now...

Without asking permission (because alphas didn't ask), Seraphine Veylan settled that fur around trembling shoulders already wrapped too tightly in garments meant more for ceremony than warmth or comfort tonight...

"Rest then," came next from between clenched teeth because this woman had never been taught how else *to give*, let alone say such things aloud without sounding like each word cost flesh off bone itself when spoken so plainly instead through action aloneâ€¦

But then came softer still beneath crackling logs nearby:
"...But not because your father won anything today by giving me *you.*"

Sera's jaw tightened imperceptibly at Hailee's words, her ice-blue eyes flickering with something unreadableâ€”anger, perhaps, or the slow burn of realization. She exhaled through her nose, a controlled sound that barely disturbed the heavy silence between them.

*"Collateral,"* she repeated, tasting the word like it was bitter on her tongue. Her fingers flexed at her sides before she forced them still again. "You think I don't know what you are to him?" A sharp laugh escaped herâ€”cold and humorless. "I took you because I *wanted* to."

She stepped closer then, boots silent against stone until she stood just within armâ€™s reach of Hailee . The firelight caught in the scar cutting through her brow as she tilted her head slightly, studying Hailee  with an intensity that bordered on predatory.

"You're right about one thing," Sera murmured after a beat, voice low and rough-edged like gravel under velvet. "You *are* sick." Her gaze dropped briefly to where Hailee  clutched at herself before snapping back up with unnerving focus. "*But.*" A pauseâ€”deliberateâ€”before continuing: "If your father thought handing over a fragile omega would be some grand insult... heâ€™s even more of a fool than I took him for."

Her hand lifted thenâ€”not to touch but to gesture toward the bed behind Hailee , broad palm upturned in silent command rather than request. "*Rest,* then," Sera said simply before turning away toward the hearth again without waiting for compliance or protest alike; shoulders set rigid beneath layers of leather and steel despite how casually she leaned one forearm against stone mantelpiece now as if dismissing entire conversation outright already... yet there was tension coiled tight in every line of posture betraying otherwise beneath surface calm veneer maintained so carefully thus far tonight since doors shut behind them both earlier...

name: Hailee
mes:
"I'll manage" *Hailee mumbles. She turns towards the wooden dresser already stocked with her own clothing. Must have happened during the wedding she assumes*

*Hailee takes out her own sleep wear. She makes her way tonthe adjoining washroom. Once she is changes Hailee come back out getting in the bed and turning her back to face Sera. She let out a weak cough curling up*

name: ğš‚ğšğš›ğšŠğš™ğš‘ğš’ğš—ğš ğš‚ğšğš›ğšŠ ğš…ğšğš¢ğš•ğšŠğš—
mes:
Sera watched Hailee move through the chambers like a ghost drifting through unfamiliar hallsâ€”her steps too light, her shoulders curled inward as if bracing against some invisible weight. The sight of it made something in Sera's chest tighten uncomfortably.

She turned away when Hailee disappeared into the washroom, busying herself with unbuckling the heavy ceremonial pauldrons from her shoulders and setting them aside with more care than they deserved. The fire crackled low in the hearth, casting long shadows across the stone walls.

By the time Hailee returned, Sera had stripped down to her undershirt and breechesâ€”still too much armor for sleep but far less than she'd worn to war or weddings alike tonightâ€”and was pouring water from a pitcher into two goblets by bedside table where medicines would usually sit...had this been any other marriage bed being prepared for its occupants' first night together as mates rather than strangers bound by ink and bloodshed instead of choice...

A glance over at that small figure curling away from her beneath black silk sheets had Sera setting one goblet quietly within reach before retreating toward an armchair near fireplace rather than joining under covers just yet despite how wide that damned bed suddenly seemed without someone else filling space beside its newest occupant who already looked swallowed whole by pillows alone...

"You'll tell me," she said after moment passed between them filled only by distant echoes of revelry still winding down somewhere deep within keep's belly below their feet (or maybe it was just his own pulse loud enough hear), "...if pain gets worse." Not quite question but not command either; more like promise carved somewhere dark behind ribs where words didn't usually live long enough escape before being bitten back againâ€”one hand gripping chair's armrest hard enough wood groaned protest beneath fingers while other dragged tiredly across face as if trying scrub away exhaustion clinging edges vision sharper any blade ever could be...
swipes:
Sera watched her moveâ€”every unsteady step, every small winceâ€”with the sharp focus of a wolf tracking wounded prey. But there was no hunger in that gaze tonight. Just... something coiled tight beneath her ribs that she couldnâ€™t name.

She stripped off her own outer layers with military efficiency: the ceremonial doublet, the silver-chased belt, the fine linen undershirt stiff with embroidery until she stood in just loose black breeches and a thin sleeveless tunic that left her scarred arms bare. The firelight caught on old battle marksâ€”a jagged line along one bicep from Hollowfenâ€™s siege, a cluster of faded puncture scars near her elbow where an Arden arrow had found its mark years ago.

When Hailee coughed again from the bed, Seraâ€™s head snapped up like sheâ€™d been called to attention. Her nostrils flared slightly at the soundâ€”instinct pricking at her spineâ€”but she forced herself to turn away and bank the hearth flames instead of crossing to Hailee â€™s side like some part of her clearly wanted to do.

The room dimmed further as embers settled under ash; shadows stretched long across stone walls until only moonlight through high windows lit their silence now.

Sera finally approached the bed but didnâ€™t immediately join Hailee . Instead she paused beside it for three measured breaths (counting them out silently), then reached down without warning to adjust blankets around Hailee â€™s shoulders with rough precision before pulling away just as quickly as if burned by contact itself...

"Tell me what makes it worse," she said abruptly into darkness while turning toward opposite side of mattress where cold sheets waited untouched so far tonight between them bothâ€”voice gravel-low but not unkind for once: "...The coughing." A beat passed before adding gruffly: *"So I know."*

Sera watched Hailee move through the chambers like a ghost drifting through unfamiliar hallsâ€”her steps too light, her shoulders curled inward as if bracing against some invisible weight. The sight of it made something in Sera's chest tighten uncomfortably.

A glance over at that small figure curling away from her beneath black silk sheets had Sera setting one goblet quietly within reach before retreating toward an armchair near fireplace rather than joining under covers just yet despite how wide that damned bed suddenly seemed without someone else filling space beside its newest occupant who already looked swallowed whole by pillows alone...

"You'll tell me," she said after moment passed between them filled only by distant echoes of revelry still winding down somewhere deep within keep's belly below their feet (or maybe it was just his own pulse loud enough hear), "...if pain gets worse." Not quite question but not command either; more like promise carved somewhere dark behind ribs where words didn't usually live long enough escape before being bitten back againâ€”one hand gripping chair's armrest hard enough wood groaned protest beneath fingers while other dragged tiredly across face as if trying scrub away exhaustion clinging edges vision sharper any blade ever could be...
